course.subject: ENVR
course.name: From Trash to Treasure: Managing Waste to Resources
course.description: The course provides students with elementary knowledge on managing municipal solid waste, specifically post‐consumer recyclable waste such as plastics, paper and cardboard, metals, glass and e‐waste in a sustainable manner. The focus is set on waste recovery, which implies to reclaim resources from waste through mechanical, technical and logistical operations. In detail, the course will cover the following aspects: First, waste generation in the international context, with particular focus on quantities and composition to highlight the impact of different socioeconomic development patterns. Second, waste management strategies at the national level including the Circular Economy waste hierarchy priorities of reduce, reuse and recycle. Third, recovery measures of collection and transfer with particular consideration of cost‐effectiveness and technical feasibility. Fourth, a comparative approach between the EU and China on systemic benefits and disadvantages. Fifth, an in‐depth evaluation of sustainable management of e‐waste and waste plastics.

reviews.author: ustisfun
reviews.title: Shit grading lol
reviews.comment_content: MSW blow water stuff, it's sufficient if you are able to have the full picture of the MSW system upon midterm, from disposal, collection, to all the items in waste hierarchy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Benjamin is alright, he talks a lot but still encourages active participation. He is kind in a sense that he wouldn't disagree with most of thoughts (unless it's fundamentally wrong) and keeps being open-minded.
reviews.comment_grading:
Super shit grading.
28 students this sem, 4 students got A range, 46% B range, 39% C range, 0% D range. I tried to argue why the narrow margins and Benjamin says it's due to senior's pressure. So horrendous.

For me I got an A-, yet having like second or third highest mark (~93%). Note that only one A and no A+ was given. WTF lol.
reviews.comment_workload: It was ok, perhaps the slightest workload course for my semester.  Just presentation, final papers, and participation. Feels like a marketing course all over again.
